title: 113_hr1949
content: The Act is titled the "Improving Postsecondary Education Data for Students Act." It includes a study on enhancing transparency in postsecondary education at the federal level. The Secretary of Education will form the Advisory Committee on Improving Postsecondary Education Data, consisting of 15 members representing diverse populations and sectors of higher education. The Advisory Committee on Improving Postsecondary Education Data will consist of 15 members representing various sectors, including state officials, students, business representatives, and experts in data policy and labor markets. The Secretary will appoint the Chairperson of the Committee, which will conduct a study on information related to postsecondary education costs, financial assistance, and student outcomes. The Federal Government should collect and report on higher education institutions to assist students and families in their search. This includes information on student outcomes disaggregated by subgroups such as full-time students, part-time students, nontraditional students, first-generation college students, veterans, and Pell Grant recipients. The Government should make this information more readily available to students and families. The Advisory Committee will examine the consistency of Federal transparency initiatives on postsecondary education and compare them to state and institutional initiatives. The Advisory Committee will assess the feasibility and impact of collecting and reporting postgraduation earnings by the Federal Government, considering its implications on student privacy and decision-making for students and families. Additionally, they will explore the relevance of other student outcome information in enhancing transparency initiatives. The Federal Government should collect and report information on student outcomes to improve transparency for students and families. This includes assessing the usefulness of current data on higher education institutions and making information more easily accessible and understandable for students and families. The Advisory Committee will review activities by various entities to inform students about Federal transparency initiatives, the cost to institutions of reporting information, and relevant research. The Advisory Committee will review questions frequently asked by students and families, types of information sought before enrolling, benefits of additional information availability, and results from transparency initiatives on postsecondary education. They will also identify any gaps in research related to these topics. The Advisory Committee will consult with parents, students, researchers, secondary schools, and institutions of higher education to gather information for the study under this Act. The Advisory Committee will consult with authorizing committees to conduct the study under this Act. They will submit an interim report within 180 days and a final report within 1 year to the authorizing committees and the Secretary. The Advisory Committee will consult with the Commissioner of Education Statistics before making recommendations for legislative, regulatory, and administrative actions based on the study findings. The final report will include recommendations and a summary of the research conducted. The study under this Act will be funded by the Secretary of Education. Definitions for terms like "authorizing committees," "first generation college student," and "institution of higher education" are provided based on the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "student" includes prospective students, those enrolled in higher education institutions, and nontraditional students as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "student" includes prospective students, enrolled higher education students, and nontraditional students as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, as well as veterans who are students or prospective students. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 22, 2013. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
